articles.headline: Robinhood’s Credit Card Offers 3% Cash Back. Can It Last?
articles.snippet: Charles Schwab stopped offering a 2 percent card years ago, and most banks don’t hand over more than 2 percent either.
articles.abstract: Charles Schwab stopped offering a 2 percent card years ago, and most banks don’t hand over more than 2 percent either.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s the first thing to know about the new Robinhood credit card that promises 3 percent cash back on all purchases, without limits: Yesterday, when I asked Vlad Tenev, the company’s chief executive, to guarantee that it would stay at that level for 18 months, he would not.

articles.headline: How the Israel-Hamas War Has Roiled TikTok Internally
articles.snippet: The video app has been criticized for how it has handled posts users see about the war. Some of the same tensions have also played out inside the company.
articles.abstract: The video app has been criticized for how it has handled posts users see about the war. Some of the same tensions have also played out inside the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Barak Herscowitz joined TikTok two years ago in the company’s Tel Aviv office, his role was to recruit Israeli government agencies and other public-sector groups to join the video service and take advantage of its popularity. His pitch: TikTok was a powerful communication tool and getting more influential in the country by the day.

articles.headline: ‘Every Day Is Hard’: One Year Since Russia Jailed a U.S. Reporter
articles.snippet: In a notorious high-security prison, Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal stays connected with supporters through letters as they keep up the pressure for his release.
articles.abstract: In a notorious high-security prison, Evan Gershkovich of The Wall Street Journal stays connected with supporters through letters as they keep up the pressure for his release.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year ago on Friday, Ella Milman and Mikhail Gershkovich received a chilling phone call from the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. Their son, Evan, a foreign correspondent for The Journal who was on a reporting assignment in Russia, had missed his daily security check-in.

articles.headline: San Francisco’s ‘Twitter Menace’ or True Believer? He Might Be Both.
articles.snippet: The deep pockets of the tech investor Garry Tan are valued by his allies, but his pugnacious online habits are creating plenty of enemies in the city he says he wants to save.
articles.abstract: The deep pockets of the tech investor Garry Tan are valued by his allies, but his pugnacious online habits are creating plenty of enemies in the city he says he wants to save.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under cathedral ceilings and soaring stained glass windows, Garry Tan clutched a microphone as he greeted a crowd of political centrists, including San Francisco’s mayor, local prosecutors and police brass.

articles.headline: Wanted in South Korea: Imperialism-Free Cherry Blossoms
articles.snippet: Activists want to replace a variety of cherry tree associated with the Japanese colonial era with one they say is Korean. The science is messy.
articles.abstract: Activists want to replace a variety of cherry tree associated with the Japanese colonial era with one they say is Korean. The science is messy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shin Joon Hwan, an ecologist, walked along a road lined with cherry trees on the verge of blooming last week, examining the fine hairs around their dark red buds.
articles.byline: By John Yoon, Mike Ives, Hisako Ueno and Chang W. Lee

articles.headline: A Loyal Israel Ally, Germany Shifts Tone as the Toll in Gaza Mounts
articles.snippet: Supporting Israel is seen as a historic duty in Germany, but the worsening crisis has pushed German officials to ask whether that backing has gone too far.
articles.abstract: Supporting Israel is seen as a historic duty in Germany, but the worsening crisis has pushed German officials to ask whether that backing has gone too far.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days after Hamas launched its Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, was one of the first Western leaders to arrive in Tel Aviv. Standing beside the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, he declared that Germany had “only one place — and it is alongside Israel.”
